Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolution of Arctic Water Column Hydrography during the Holocene Based on a Novel Instrumentation Combination
Award.AbstractNarration:
During the past few decades, the Arctic has warmed approximately twice as rapidly as the entire northern hemisphere, associated with substantial retreat and thinning of the Arctic sea-ice cover during the past decade. Associated with the Arctic warming and waning sea-ice cover is a reorganization of the surface and deep-water circulation of the Arctic Ocean, but understanding of the associated processes is limited. The early to mid-Holocene provides a post-glacial analogue of a seasonally ice-free Arctic Ocean, similar to scenarios that have been proposed for the next several decades. This early-mid Holocene sea ice minimum, 10?6 thousand years ago, is often attributed to changes in solar forcing. However, records providing information on upper Arctic water column stratification during episodes of minimum sea ice cover are sparse. The normal paleoceanographic proxies for water mass stratification cannot be applied in the Arctic; different approaches are required to reconstruct water column hydrography. The proposed research has the potential to greatly improve our knowledge of past Arctic water column hydrography from the early to mid-Holocene sea ice minimum and inform scenario development of future conditions in the Arctic Ocean.

The project will contribute to workforce development through support for the training of a PhD student. The technology developed will be proactively transferred to the international science community through a formal workshop.

Recent innovations in the combined use of secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS), laser-ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (laser-ablation ICP-MS) and Isotope ratio mass spectrometry (IRMS) have shown that a wealth of environmental information about water column stratification can be extracted from single shells of fossil foraminifera. Neogloboquadrina pachyderma (sinistral) (Nps), grows its chambers (ontogenetic calcite) near the Arctic surface, and subsequently sinks through the water column where it adds a thick calcite crust around the thinly calcified chambers at sub-mixed layer depths. Thus, each individual Nps shell contains chemical and isotopic zonation from waters with distinctly different physical properties ? the generally cold low salinity surface mixed layer and warmer subsurface halocline. Intrashell variability can be measured with in situ analytical approaches. The principal investigators (PIs) propose to apply a multi-instrument approach to quantify intrashell geochemistry in Nps shells obtained from an array of boxcore samples across the Arctic Ocean. They plan to combine intrashell ä18O and ä13C measurements in <5 ìm-sized domains by SIMS with analyses of Mg/Ca (proxy for temperature), Ba/Ca (proxy for river runoff or meltwater discharge), and Na/Ca (proxy for salinity) by laser-ablation ICP-MS on the same Nps shells. The innovative SIMS ultra-small domain isotope analytical approach was developed within the last few years by PI Kozdon, and calibrated in the lab of PI Spero. Both SIMS (spot-measurements) and laser-ablation data (depth profiles through the calcite layers) can be correlated to well defined domains in the foraminiferal shells that reflect a specific stage in the specimens? ontogenetic development (?time-markers?). Each of the measurements can be assigned to a general water depth range that is related to the depth of calcite addition as Nps migrates through the water column during its ontogenetic development. Thus, the proposed analytical approach provides an unprecedented opportunity to reconstruct past water column stratification between the surface and halocline from individual shells of Nps in sedimentary assemblages. This innovative multi-instrument approach will be applied to mid-Holocene and late Holocene Nps shells from ~50 14C-dated box-coretop samples from the Arctic Ocean. The cores will be carefully selected, mainly from U.S. core repositories, using the following criteria: (I) good coverage of the Arctic Ocean with a focus on key-areas sensitive to changes in water mass stratification and (II) existing 14C dates, although some of the cores will still need to be dated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past decades, the Arctic has warmed approximately twice as rapidly as the entire northern hemisphere, associated with a substantial retreat and thinning of the Arctic sea-ice cover. This decrease in Arctic sea ice is one of the most striking manifestations of global climate change. The early to mid-Holocene (10 - 6 ky) provides a post-glacial analogue of a seasonally ice-free Arctic Ocean, similar to scenarios that have been proposed for the next several decades. Thus, accurate paleoclimate records from the early to mid-Holocene help to improve model simulations predicting the rate and magnitude of future Arctic climate change that will likely impact the entire northern Hemisphere.

Much of our knowledge about the climate evolution of the Arctic region is deduced from chemical analyses of fossil shells of a planktonic organism – a single celled species of foraminifera called Neogloboquadrina. pachyderma (Np). The sand-grain sized calcite shells of these marine protozoa contain chemical and isotopic information related to environmental conditions when the organism formed its shell, thereby allowing researchers to reconstruct physical parameters such as temperature and salinity for the Arctic in the past.  

However, Np, like most planktonic foraminifera, has a complex lifecycle. This species adds new chambers (ontogenetic calcification) in surface waters, followed by a heavy crust that is added at deeper depths below the mixed layer (typically well below 50 m). Thus, Np shells are a heterogeneous mix of calcite that was precipitated in waters with different temperature and salinity characteristics.

Due to their small size (less than 0.5 mm in diameter), entire Np shells are typically grouped so sample mass is sufficient for a chemical analysis. Thus, the past data represents a mixture of the different generations of calcite, and the complex life history of different organisms is averaged in each analysius. This is problematic in cases where different specimens grow in different seasons (the lifecycle of these organisms is one month) and each shell features a thick crust, as this final calcite layer may contribute more than 50% to the whole shell and thus shifts the whole-shell composition to properties found in the deeper water column.

In this study, we used laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass-spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) to mill small holes (~0.05 mm) through the foraminiferal chamber walls (depth profiling). Similar to tree-ring records reflecting the growth history of the entire tree, LA-ICP-MS allows us to resolve the different layers of calcite in foraminiferal shells, and the chemical information (in particular the Magnesium/Calcium ratios, which are sensitive to water temperature) of the ontogenetic calcite, that has formed in the upper water column, can be separated from the crust calcite that has been precipitated in deeper waters. This provides the novel opportunity to reconstruct surface ocean conditions by excluding the "unwanted" deep-water signal of the crust.

The possibility to extract new paleoclimate information from fossil Np shells was further explored by using a new approach that combines analyses of Barium/Calcium ratios, which are sensitive to salinity, with measurements of the oxygen isotope composition (δ18O) in the same shells. In concert, these measurements allowed us to reconstruct of the oxygen isotope geochemistry of an ancient Canadian lake, Lake Agassiz, that flooded the Arctic Ocean 12,000 years ago and led to the 1000 year Younger Dryas cooling event in the North Atlantic that caused deep Atlantic ocean currents to slow down. The quantification of the oxygen isotope composition of meltwater pulses can be used to inform and update modelling studies aimed at understanding the effect of low-salinity, low-density meltwater on the global oceanic circulation. A better understanding of the response of ocean circulation to meltwater pulses is critical as the global ice volume is decreasing at an increasing rate.

Results from this study have been presented at international conferences and publications in the public domain (Livsey et al., 2020; Paleoceanography and Paleoclimatology) and in preparation.
